start.title:
Shaping Digital Beats

Exploring ADSR and Function Transformations
start.description: Join Dr. Ava Whitaker and Micah Daniels in a hands-on journey through digital synthesis! In this STEAMQuest, you'll explore the ADSR envelope and use function transformations to shape the sound of digital drums.

S2_D1_F4_C0.heading: Welcome to the world of sound design!
S2_D1_F4_C0.body: I’m Dr. Ava Whitaker, and alongside me is Micah Daniels, a keen learner who’s eager to explore how math is applied in music. Together, we'll use ADSR and function transformations to control how sounds evolve over time, from their sharp attack to their smooth release.

S3_D0_FX_C9.title: Digital Synthesizer
S3_D0_FX_C9.description: A modern digital synthesizer featuring a waveform display and four LED-lit ADSR control knobs labeled Attack, Decay, Sustain, and Release.
S3_D0_FX_C9.alt: Digital synthesizer with a display and control dials.

S3.S3_D1_F3_C2: Whoa, that looks awesome! What are you working on?
S3.S3_D2_F4_C1: I'm shaping a drum sound using a digital synthesizer. See this waveform? Every time I tweak these controls, it changes how the sound behaves over time.
S3.S3_D3_F5_C2: I see the rotary knobs labeled Attack, Decay, Sustain, and Release… What do they do?
S3.S3_D4_F6_C1: Good question! These four controls make up what's called the ADSR envelope. They define how a sound plays out over time, from start to finish.
S3.S3_D5_F7_C2: So, does every sound have an ADSR?
S3.S3_D6_F8_C1: Pretty much! But before we dive into how it works, let's first hear what a sound is like without ADSR applied.
S3.S3_D7_F9_C2: Alright, let's check it out!

about.heading: Raw Drum Sounds Without ADSR
about.body:
• Kick Drum: The kick drum is a low-pitched drum sound that typically provides the pulse or foundation of a beat
  • Cymbal: A cymbal is a high-pitched, metallic percussion instrument often used to emphasize a rhythmic pattern or add texture
  • Raw Sound: These sounds are played without any ADSR envelope shaping, showing how drums sound in their most basic form

help.heading: How to use this tool
help.body:
• Play the Beat: Press the Play button to hear both the kick drum and cymbal playing together at a fixed tempo
  • Test Individual Sounds: Click on the Kick or Cymbal buttons to hear each instrument individually and understand their basic characteristics

drumSetup.ariaLabel: A drum setup having one Kick Drum and Cymbal.

S4.S4_D1_F10_C1: Press the Play button and hear what it sounds like without ADSR.
S4.S4_D2_F11_C2: Oh, that's… really abrupt. Each beat just starts and stops instantly, with no flow at all.
S4.S4_D3_F12_C1: Yes. This is the most basic version of a drum sound. The sound's amplitude jumps instantly to its peak and then drops back to zero, with no transition. The lack of smooth transitions is what makes it feel abrupt.
S4.S4_D4_F13_C2: So, what kind of drum is this?
S4.S4_D5_F14_C1: That's a kick drum—it's the deep, low-pitched beat that gives any melody its pulse. In most music, it's used to drive the rhythm.
S4.S4_D6_F15_C2: And what about the other one?
S4.S4_D7_F16_C1: That's the cymbal. It's the high-pitched metallic sound that rings out, often used to add emphasis in a beat.
S4.S4_D8_F17_C2: Got it. So kick for the deep beat and cymbal for the bright crashes.
S4.S4_D9_F18_C1: Right. Since we haven't applied ADSR yet, right now, every beat just starts and stops instantly—no smoothness, no natural fade.
S4.S4_D10_F19_C2: Okay, I get it now. But can you now explain to me about ADSR?

S5_D0_F24_C9.title: The ADSR Envelope
S5_D0_F24_C9.longDescription: A technical diagram showing the ADSR (Attack, Decay, Sustain, Release) envelope, which is fundamental in sound synthesis. The graph displays amplitude over time, with clear sections marked for each phase. The Attack phase shows the initial rise from zero to maximum amplitude, followed by the Decay phase where the sound drops to the Sustain level. The Sustain phase maintains a constant amplitude while the key is held, and finally, the Release phase shows how the sound fades to silence after the key is released. Each section is color-coded and clearly labeled with detailed explanations of their functions.
S5_D0_F24_C9.alt: Sound envelope diagram showing Attack, Decay, Sustain and Release phases.

S5.S5_D1_F24_C1:
Let me break it down:
  • Attack is the beginning. It's how quickly the sound reaches full volume when you trigger a beat. A sharp attack makes it hit instantly, while a slow attack fades in smoothly
  • Decay comes next. It's how quickly the sound drops after that initial peak
  • Sustain is the middle—it's the volume level the sound holds while it plays
  • Release is the end. It's how the sound fades out after the beat stops
S5.S5_D2_F25_C2: So these stages control how a sound evolves over time?
S5.S5_D3_F26_C1: Exactly! And each stage follows a mathematical function we can adjust. The attack phase is especially important because it shapes how the sound starts. Let's begin by adjusting that.

about.heading: Attack Phase Transformations: Understanding the Changes
about.body:
• Attack phase: Defines how quickly the amplitude reaches its peak after the sound is triggered
  • Vertical Shift(f of t plus k)(f(t) + k): Increasing this value will move the graph up and make the sound start louder, while decreasing it will move the graph down and make the sound start quieter.
  • Horizontal Shift(f of t plus k)(f(t + k)): Increasing this value will move the graph to the right and delay the start of the attack phase, while decreasing it will move the graph to the left and make the attack phase start sooner.
  • Vertical Scale(k times f of t)(k × f(t)): Increasing this value will stretch the graph vertically and make the sound louder, while decreasing it will compress the graph vertically and make the sound quieter.
  • Horizontal Scale(f of k times t)(f(k × t)): Increasing this value will compress the graph horizontally, making the sound reach full volume faster, while decreasing it will stretch the graph horizontally, making the sound reach full volume more slowly.

help.heading: How to Use Attack Phase Transformations
help.body:
• Adjust the Sliders: Use the four sliders to manipulate the Vertical Shift, Vertical Scale, Horizontal Scale, and Horizontal Shift of the attack phase. Each slider affects a different aspect of the sound's attack
  • Match the Target Curve: Your goal is to match the gray dashed curve
  • Test with Kick Drum: After adjusting the sliders, press Play to hear the sound with your transformations applied. You can test the changes you've made to the attack phase and listen to how the sound evolves

S6.S6_D1_F27_C1: The attack phase controls how quickly the sound builds up when a beat starts.
S6.S6_D2_F28_C2: So, it's like the first impression of the sound?
S6.S6_D3_F29_C1: Yes. Here, the attack phase is modeled by a simple linear function: f(t) = 10t. That means the amplitude increases steadily over time.
S6.S6_D4_F30_C2: Okay, so it's just a straight line going up?
S6.S6_D5_F31_C1: Right. The function creates a smooth, predictable increase in volume from the moment the beat is triggered. Now let's modify it.
S6.S6_D6_F32_C2: But why would I need to change that? Doesn't the smooth increase work fine?
S6.S6_D7_F33_C1: In some cases, sure. But adjusting how fast the volume rises changes how the sound feels. A slow attack makes it fade in softly, while a fast attack gives it a sharp, punchy start.
S6.S6_D8_F34_C2: Oh, so if the attack is too fast, the sound might feel too harsh, and if it's too slow, it might not stand out?
S6.S6_D9_F35_C1: Right, that's where function transformations come in. By adjusting the slope, shifts, and scale, you can fine-tune both the timing and intensity of the attack.
S6.S6_D10_F36_C2: Got it! So, the function gives me a basic structure, and transformations help me shape it the way I want?
S6.S6_D11_F37_C1: You got it. Now, let's try modifying the attack phase step by step!
S6.S6_D12_F38_C1: Let's start with Vertical Shift (f(t) + k). It moves the graph up or down, adjusting the starting volume.
S6.S6_D13_F39_C2: So if I lower it, the sound starts quieter, like it's fading in from a distance?
S6.S6_D14_F40_C1: Yes. Now, Horizontal Shift (f(t + k)) moves the graph left or right, changing when the attack phase begins. A right shift delays the sound, while a left shift makes it start sooner.
S6.S6_D15_F41_C2: Oh, so shifts don't change the shape of the attack—just when it starts or how loud it begins?
S6.S6_D16_F42_C1: That's right. Shifts only change its starting position and starting sound level.
S6.S6_D17_F43_C1: Now that we've looked at shifting, let's talk about scales. Scaling is important because it lets us adjust the intensity and duration of the sound's attack, making it fit the needs of the composition.
S6.S6_D18_F44_C2: So, scaling helps control how dramatic or smooth the attack feels?
S6.S6_D19_F45_C1: Vertical Scale (k × f(t)) stretches or compresses the graph vertically, affecting intensity. Scaling up makes the attack stronger, while scaling down softens it.
S6.S6_D20_F46_C2: Oh! So a taller graph means the sound gets louder, but not necessarily faster?
S6.S6_D21_F47_C1: That's correct. Now, the speed of attack phase is controlled by Horizontal Scale (f(k × t)). It stretches or compresses the graph horizontally, changing how long the attack phase lasts.
S6.S6_D22_F48_C2: So if I compress it horizontally, the attack happens much faster, like a sharp entrance?
S6.S6_D23_F49_C1: Right, scaling reshapes the attack—affecting how quickly and intensely the sound builds, without shifting the whole graph.
S6.S6_D24_F50_C1: Before we start transforming the curve, let's understand why we aim to match f(t) = 10t.
S6.S6_D25_F51_C2: Why this equation for the attack phase?
S6.S6_D26_F52_C1: f(t) = 10t is a simple linear function that gives a clean, smooth rise in volume, ideal for a quick yet controlled attack.
S6.S6_D27_F53_C2: So it ensures the sound builds steadily instead of jumping to full volume?
S6.S6_D28_F54_C1: Yes! Now that we understand why we use 10t as a reference, let's apply the transformations to fine-tune the attack phase and match the gray dashed target curve.
S6.S6_D29_F55_C2: It's amazing how each transformation worked together. The vertical changes controlled how loud the sound felt, and the horizontal changes adjusted the timing.
S6.S6_D30_F56_C1: That's right! The attack phase sets the tone for how a sound begins. With these transformations, you now have the tools to shape it precisely, making beats sound smooth and natural.
S6.S6_D31_F57_C2: That makes sense. Adjusting the attack properly helps the beats feel more controlled instead of too sudden.
S6.S6_D32_F58_C1: Next, we'll look at the entire ADSR envelope—how the sound evolves from start to finish.

S7_D0_FX_C9.title: ADSR Envelope Function
S7_D0_FX_C9.body:
f(t)

=

{

fattack(t),

fdecay(t),

fsustain(t),

frelease(t),

0,

0 ≤ t < A

A ≤ t < A + D

A + D ≤ t < tr

tr ≤ t < tr + R

t ≥ tr + R

Where,

f(t) is the amplitude at time t

A is the attack duration

D is the decay duration

R is the release duration

tr​ is the time when the note is released

S is the sustain level (a constant value)

S7_X.S7_D1_FX_C1: The ADSR envelope describes how a sound's amplitude changes over time. Since each phase behaves differently, we model it with a piecewise function.
S7_X.S7_D2_FX_C2: So different equations apply depending on what phase the sound is in?
S7_X.S7_D3_FX_C1: Exactly. Each segment handles a specific time range. Let's go through each one.
S7_X.S7_D4_FX_C1: The Attack phase, starting at time t = 0, is linear growth up to a peak amplitude at time t = A, which is the attack duration.
S7_X.S7_D5_FX_C1: Then comes the Decay phase. From t = A to t = A + D, the amplitude decreases from the peak to the sustain level S, where D is the decay duration.
S7_X.S7_D6_FX_C1: The Sustain phase begins at t = A + D and lasts as long as the note is held. During this phase, the amplitude stays constant at the sustain level S.
S7_X.S7_D7_FX_C1: When the note is released at time t = tr, the Release phase starts. Over the next R units of time, the amplitude drops from S to 0, ending at t = tr + R.
S7_X.S7_D8_FX_C2: Got it. So the amplitude just follows the shape defined by those four phases.
S7_X.S7_D9_FX_C1: Precisely. Each one shapes the sound in time — from the very start to the moment it fades out.

about.heading: ADSR Envelope Transformations: Understanding the Changes
about.body:
ADSR Envelope: The ADSR envelope defines the shape of a sound over time, broken into four phases:

  • Attack: The initial rise in amplitude, from zero to peak
  • Decay: The drop in amplitude after the peak, leading to the sustain level
  • Sustain: The steady amplitude while the note is held
  • Release: The gradual fade-out of sound after the note is released

Transformation Parameters:

  • Vertical Shift: Moves the graph up or down, adjusting the starting volume or baseline level of the sound without changing its shape.
  • Horizontal Shift: Moves the graph left or right, adjusting when each ADSR phase begins in time.
  • Vertical Scale: Stretches or compresses the graph vertically, increasing or decreasing the volume of the sound across the ADSR phases.
  • Horizontal Scale: Stretches or compresses the graph horizontally, changing the duration of each phase (e.g., how quickly the sound reaches full volume).

help.heading: How to Use ADSR Transformation
help.body:
• Adjust the Sliders: You can modify the Vertical Shift, Vertical Scale, Horizontal Scale, and Horizontal Shift parameters to transform the ADSR envelope
  • Match the Target Envelope: Your goal is to match the solid curve to the dashed curve. You will see a checkmark (✓) when the sliders are accurately positioned
  • Test with Kick Drum: After adjusting the sliders, press the Play button to listen to how the transformations impact the ADSR envelope and the overall sound

translations.adsrValuesLabel: ADSR Values: Attack = 0.01s, Decay = 0.2s, Sustain = 80%, Sustain Time = 0.2s, Release = 0.2s

S7.S7_D10_F64_C1: Now, let's apply these concepts. Your goal is to match the gray dashed curve, which represents a target ADSR envelope. Use the sliders to adjust the amplitude and timing for each phase.
S7.S7_D11_F65_C2: Why are we matching it?
S7.S7_D12_F66_C1: Because this target curve represents the ideal sound shape we want to create for our kick drum. Matching it ensures the sound evolves in a smooth, natural way, fitting the rhythm.
S7.S7_D13_F67_C2: Got it! Let me give it a try and match the curve.
S7.S7_D14_F68_C2: Adjusting the sliders really helped me understand how each phase controls how a sound develops and fades over time.
S7.S7_D15_F69_C1: Well done, Micah! By learning these transformations, you can now shape not just the attack phase, but the entire way a sound evolves in a beat.
S7.S7_D16_F70_C2: This makes so much sense now. I see how adjusting the envelope lets the sound flow naturally instead of feeling too abrupt.
S7.S7_D17_F71_C1: Great job adjusting the ADSR envelope for the kick drum! Now, let's apply the same concept to the cymbal.

  • Vertical Shift: Moves the graph up or down, adjusting the starting volume or baseline level of the sound without changing its shape.
  • Horizontal Shift: Moves the graph left or right, adjusting when each ADSR phase begins in time.
  • Vertical Scale: Stretches or compresses the graph vertically, increasing or decreasing the volume of the sound across the ADSR phases.
  • Horizontal Scale: Stretches or compresses the graph horizontally, changing the duration of each phase (e.g., how quickly the sound reaches full volume).

help.heading: How to Use ADSR Transformation
help.body:
• Adjust the Sliders: You can modify the Vertical Shift, Vertical Scale, Horizontal Scale, and Horizontal Shift parameters to transform the ADSR envelope
  • Match the Target Envelope: Your goal is to match the solid curve to the dashed curve. You will see a checkmark (✓) when the sliders are accurately positioned
  • Test with Cymbal: After adjusting the sliders, press the Play button to listen to how the transformations impact the ADSR envelope and the overall sound

S8.S8_D1_F72_C2: Oh, right! The cymbal doesn't hit like a kick drum—it rings out for a while.
S8.S8_D2_F73_C1: Exactly! The attack is usually very short, but the release is much longer since the sound naturally fades over time. Your goal is to match the gray dashed target curve for the cymbal's ADSR envelope.
S8.S8_D3_F74_C2: Tuning the settings really helped me see how each phase controls how the cymbal's sound builds and fades.
S8.S8_D4_F75_C1: Well done, Micah! Now you can shape not just short, punchy sounds like the kick drum, but also long, ringing sounds like the cymbal.

about.heading: ADSR Sound Shaping
about.body:
• Kick Drum: The kick drum is a low-pitched drum sound that typically provides the pulse or foundation of a beat
  • Cymbal: A cymbal is a high-pitched, metallic percussion instrument often used to emphasize a rhythmic pattern or add texture

help.heading: ADSR Beat Shaper: Understanding the Controls
help.body: • Adjusting the ADSR: Use the ADSR values found earlier for each of the instrument and hear the difference

S9.S9_D1_F76_C1: Now that you understand the ADSR envelope, let's apply it to shape the final sound. Can you recall how each phase works?
S9.S9_D2_F77_C2: Yeah! Attack controls how the sound begins, decay adjusts how it settles after the peak, sustain determines how long it holds, and release controls how it fades out.
S9.S9_D3_F78_C1: Yes, earlier, we explored how transformations affect these phases. But before we apply our final ADSR values—let's hear the beat again without any shaping. Click the Play button.
S9.S9_D4_F79_C2: Right, it still sounds rough and harsh. Nothing flows or holds.
S9.S9_D5_F80_C1: That's because it's missing dynamic shaping. Now, let's apply the final ADSR values we arrived at to both the kick drum and cymbal.
S9.S9_D6_F81_C2: So, these are the values we determined earlier—not new transformations?
S9.S9_D7_F82_C1: That's right! These settings give each beat proper balance, helping each sound take its space and feel more intentional.
S9.S9_D8_F83_C1:
Adjust the ADSR values for the kick drum and hear the difference. Use the sliders to set the values we established earlier.
  • Attack: 0.01s for a sharp impact
  • Decay: 0.2s to control the drop-off
  • Sustain: 0.8 (80% amplitude) to keep the body of the sound
  • Release: 0.2s for a clean finish
S9.S9_D9_FX_C1:
Now switch to cymbal and adjust the ADSR values for it. Use the sliders to set the values.
  • Attack: 0.1s for a smooth onset
  • Decay: 0.4s to let it settle
  • Sustain: 0.1 (10% amplitude) to maintain a subtle presence
  • Release: 0.8s for a natural fade-out
S9.S9_D10_FX_C1: Great! Now that we’ve adjusted the ADSR values let’s hear the beat again. Click the Play button.
S9.S9_D11_F84_C2: Whoa! The kick sounds controlled, and the cymbal rings out smoothly. Everything feels more balanced now.
S9.S9_D12_F85_C1: Right, by shaping each sound with ADSR, we control how they interact, making the beat sound natural and well-defined.

S10.S10_D1_F86_C2: Thank you, Dr. Whitaker. Understanding the math behind sound shaping has completely changed how I think about music. Now, I have the tools to adjust ADSR and shape beats with precision.
S10.S10_D2_F87_C1: You've done an incredible job, Micah! Music is where math and creativity meet, and now you can use both to craft any sound exactly how you want it.
S10.S10_D3_F88_C2: Yeah! It's amazing how small adjustments can change the entire feel of a beat. I never realized how much control ADSR gives over sound.
S10.S10_D4_F89_C1: Exactly! Whether you're working with a drum kit, a synth, or even a live instrument, these concepts help shape the way sound moves and evolves.

quest_completion.subheading: You've explored ADSR and Function Transformations
quest_completion.content:
Congratulations! You completed the Mathematics of Music STEAMQuest

  • •You helped Dr. Ava Whitaker shape dynamic beats using the ADSR envelope
  • •You explored how function transformations impact the amplitude and timing across the Attack, Decay, Sustain, and Release phases
  • •You gained experience with piecewise-defined functions to refine the dynamics of both the kick drum and cymbal
  • •You applied mathematical tools to shape beats and create a natural flow in your composition

Keep going! Your journey of shaping sound with math continues.

adsr_envelope.definition: An ADSR envelope is a way to shape the amplitude (loudness) of a sound over time, particularly in synthesizers. ADSR stands for Attack, Decay, Sustain, and Release, which are the four parameters that define the envelope's behavior.

function_transformations.definition: Function Transformations are modifications made to the graph of a function, such as translations, reflections, stretches, or compressions, that change its position or shape on a coordinate plane.

amplitude.definition: Amplitude is the measure of the strength or intensity of a sound wave.

envelope.definition: Envelope refers to the shape of a sound's amplitude over time.

piecewise_function.definition: Piecewise Function is a mathematical function defined by different expressions for different intervals of the input variable.

pitch.definition: Pitch refers to the perceived frequency of a sound, determining whether it sounds high or low.

digital_synthesizer.definition: Digital Synthesizer is an electronic instrument that is used to generate and manipulate sound, allowing for a wide range of tones, effects, and musical expressions.

note.definition: A note is a single sound that is played or sung. It starts when the sound begins and ends when it stops.
